projects.title: NOVAIR (EU Horizon 2020 Clean Sky 2)
projects.description:
As a part of the EU Clean Sky 2 research programme, the NOVAIR (Novel Aircraft Configurations and Scaled Flight Testing Instrumentation) project focuses on the design of radical aircraft configurations which promise significant improvements in terms of efficiency and sustainability, by incorporating technologies such as hybrid electric propulsion (HEP), distributed propulsion (DP), or boundary-layer ingestion (BLI).

In this joint effort between NLR and Delft University of Technology, the Flight Performance and Propulsion (FPP) group will develop a framework for the design of radical aircraft concepts featuring hybrid electric propulsion systems, with a focus on the applicability to posterior scaled flight testing (SFT) and instrumentation.

projects.title: Unsteady Pylon Loading for Pylon-Mounted Tractor Propellers: an Experimental Study (MSc thesis)
projects.description:
The high efficiency of open-rotor propulsion has led to a renewed interest in these systems over the past years. However, due to one of their main drawbacks - propeller noise - there is an increasing need for investigation on this topic and possible new configurations.

As a part of the Master's degree in Aerospace Engineering, this ten-month project aimed to identify and quantify sources of unsteady pylon loading in a tractor propeller-pylon configuration. For this it was necessary to:

► Characterize propeller slipstream impingement and aerodynamic interaction.
► Determine the contribution of these phenomena to unsteady pylon loading.
► Identify the effect of key parameters (operating conditions and geometry).
► Link the unsteady pylon loading to structureborne cabin noise.

The study was carried out experimentally in the Low Turbulence Wind Tunnel (LTT) facility at Delft University of Technology, using measurement techniques such as Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) for flow characterization and load computation and microphones for unsteady surface pressure measurements.

projects.title: San Francisco Aerial System of Transportation (F.A.S.T.)
projects.description:
Considering the increasing amount of traffic congestions in large metropolitan areas with ever-growing populations and the continuous dissolution of technological limitations, air taxi systems are no longer a utopia. 

Our team of eight members has worked on an innovative solution which will allow people to get in and out of the city by means of an aerial transport network. The team has analysed several different concepts, coming up with a hybrid aircraft configuration which combines electrical propulsion and autorrotation to provide a means of transport on short ranges, allowing both vertical and horizontal take-off and landing (VSTOL).

As part of the annual AIAA graduate design competition for Master students around the world, the project has come up with a business and operations plan for the network as well as the from-scratch design of the aircraft, as our team members connect the different disciplines of aerospace engineering to come up with a safe and efficient aircraft, minimizing operational costs as well as environmental impact.

projects.title: Development of a test bench for a mini-Wankel engine (BSc Thesis)
projects.description:
The objective of this project is to prepare a test bench capable of measuring the performances of a miniature rotary engine and obtaining its performance curves, allowing future researches on fuel mixtures and engine configurations to find the most efficient operating points if used as a portable power supply or a propulsion system for small UAV's.

The different components and instruments are programmed using LabVIEW (PID control, data acquisition, etc.) and calibrated (brake, throttle, load cell, etc.), setting up a functional test bench capable of measuring and controlling the different variables of the engine up to 11.000 RPM.
